speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me exactly when your symptoms started, and did anything trigger them?

speaker: Patient
text: I remember it started about three days ago, I woke up with some pain in my left wrist, but it wasn't too bad at first. It got worse yesterday and this morning it's really been hurting, especially when I move my wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you seem a bit anxious, is there something in particular that's causing you concern or making you worried about your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I'm a bit worried about the rash on my hands and wrists. It's just been really itchy and uncomfortable. I'm not sure what it is or if it's related to the pain in my wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms starting a few weeks ago, and you mentioned that nothing in particular triggered them. Can you tell me if you've experienced any recent travel or exposure to anyone who's been sick?

speaker: Patient
text: I did recently go on a camping trip to Minnesota with some friends. We spent a few days outdoors, and I remember getting a bit of a chill on the last night because it was really cold.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that you haven't traveled recently, but have you been in contact with anyone who's been sick, like a family member or a friend?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, I've been pretty isolated since I got back from the camping trip. But to be honest, my girlfriend was feeling a bit off before I left, and we had some... intimate contact.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've been in close contact with a family member who's been unwell, that's good to know. Have you been taking care of that family member in any way, such as helping with their daily needs or giving them medication?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my girlfriend wasn't that sick, she just had a bit of a fever and was feeling pretty crummy, so I didn't really do anything to help her, just kept some distance. But we did spend some time together before I left for the camping trip.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses so far. Have you noticed any specific patterns or times of day when your symptoms seem to worsen or improve?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, my wrist pain seems to get worse when I first wake up and when I'm doing activities that involve moving my wrist, like typing on my phone. It feels a bit better when I'm just sitting still, but even then, the rash on my hands and wrists still itches like crazy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss or loss of appetite since your symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I have been feeling a bit hungrier than usual, I think I've been eating a bit more to try and cope with the pain. But I wouldn't say I've lost any weight, I'm still about the same size as I was before.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your skin lesions since they first appeared, such as them getting larger or changing color?

speaker: Patient
text: The rash on my hands and wrists seems to be spreading, but it's not getting any bigger or changing color, it's just kind of... multiplying, I guess. And it's really itchy, like I said before.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've also noticed that you seem to be rubbing your wrist a bit, can you tell me more about the pain you're experiencing in that area?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a sharp, stabbing pain, especially when I move my wrist or try to rotate it. Sometimes it feels like there's a burning sensation too, like my skin is on fire.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain in your wrist is quite concerning, can you tell me if the pain is constant or does it come and go throughout the day?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been pretty constant, to be honest. The pain is always there, but it does get a bit better when I'm just sitting still. But as soon as I try to move my wrist, it starts hurting again.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the pain in your wrist to me in more detail - is it a sharp stabbing sensation, a dull ache, or more of a burning feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a sharp, stabbing pain, especially when I move my wrist or try to rotate it. Sometimes it feels like there's a burning sensation too, like my skin is on fire. It's really uncomfortable and makes it hard for me to even move my wrist without wincing in pain.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain in your wrist is quite concerning, I'd like to examine it more closely. Can you show me exactly where the pain is located and if it's affecting your ability to move your wrist or hand?

speaker: Patient
text: It's mainly on the top and side of my wrist, and it's making it really hard to move my wrist or hand without feeling that sharp pain. Sometimes it feels like my wrist is locked in place, and I have to really force it to move.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain seems to be located in the middle of your wrist, and you mentioned it's affecting your ability to move your wrist or hand. Have you noticed any difficulty gripping objects or performing daily activities due to this pain?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, it's been really tough to grip things or even hold onto objects for more than a few seconds without feeling that sharp pain. It's also been hard to do simple things like buttoning my shirt or even typing on my phone because of the discomfort in my wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken a closer look at your wrist and I notice some swelling around the area where the pain is located. Have you noticed any redness or warmth in that area as well?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the area around my wrist is pretty red and warm to the touch. It feels like it's inflamed or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the swelling and redness around your wrist. Have you experienced any fever or chills associated with your wrist pain, or is the fever more generalized?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I've been feeling really cold and clammy, especially in the past 24 hours. I've had a bit of a fever, but it's not been super high, maybe around 100 or 101. But the chills are what really get me, they're just so uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned earlier that you've been in close contact with a family member who's been unwell, and I have to admit, I'm a bit concerned about the possibility of an infectious disease. Can you tell me more about your family member's symptoms and if they've been diagnosed with anything yet?

speaker: Patient
text: My girlfriend was feeling pretty crummy, like I said before. She had a fever and was just feeling really unwell, but she didn't see a doctor or anything, she just kind of... rode it out, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family member's symptoms, but I still need to clarify a few things. Have you been wearing any protective gear, such as gloves, when caring for your family member?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I don't think so. We didn't really take any precautions like that, we just kind of... took care of each other, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family member's symptoms and your precautions while caring for them. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms in yourself, such as fatigue, headaches, or muscle aches, in addition to the wrist pain, fever, and skin lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I have been feeling pretty exhausted lately, even when I'm just sitting around. It's like I have no energy to do anything, and I'm always feeling really tired. And yeah, I've had some headaches too, they're not too bad, but they're definitely there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in your fingers or hand, in addition to the wrist pain?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, yeah, I have noticed some numbness in my fingers, especially my left hand, which is the same side as my wrist pain. It's not constant, but it's definitely there sometimes, especially when I'm trying to move my wrist or hand.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've asked you 19 questions, and now it's time for me to consider all the information you've provided. I have to admit, I'm a bit concerned about the possibility of an infectious disease, especially given your close contact with a family member who's been unwell.

Before I make a diagnosis, I'd like to request some test results to help confirm my suspicions. REQUEST TEST: Skin_Biopsy.
